episodes.description: It's a jam packed ultimate recap episode! We kick it off with an indepth discussion about World Athletic's Ultimate Championships and its impact on the sports. We cover New York City Grand Prix with Sage Hurta-Klecker's big W and Eric Holt's duel with Jake Wightman. We also talk a bit about Fred Kerley's big day and Sydney Mclaughlin's impressive open 400m as well. We jump into some NCAA Championship recap including the men and women's distance events and also get into the European Champs a bit. We live react to Jakob Ingebrigtsen's 1500m and earning a triple double gold. I probably am forgetting even more, so check out the episode and enjoy!Follow us here:Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/coffeeclubpod/George Beamish: https://www.instagram.com/georgebeamish/Morgan McDonald: https://www.instagram.com/morganmcdonald__/Olli Hoare: https://www.instagram.com/ollihoare/Coffee Club Merch: https://coffeeclubpod.comMorgan's discord: https://discord.gg/uaCSeHDpgsMorgan's YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/@MorganMcDonaldisaloserIntro Artwork by The Orange Runner: https://www.instagram.com/theorangerunner/Intro Music by Nick Harris: https://open.spotify.com/artist/3Zab8WxvAPsDlhlBTcbuPi
episodes.html_description:
It's a jam packed ultimate recap episode! We kick it off with an indepth discussion about World Athletic's Ultimate Championships and its impact on the sports. We cover New York City Grand Prix with Sage Hurta-Klecker's big W and Eric Holt's duel with Jake Wightman. We also talk a bit about Fred Kerley's big day and Sydney Mclaughlin's impressive open 400m as well. We jump into some NCAA Championship recap including the men and women's distance events and also get into the European Champs a bit. We live react to Jakob Ingebrigtsen's 1500m and earning a triple double gold. I probably am forgetting even more, so check out the episode and enjoy!

Topics discussed include Kipchoge's new sponsorship deal with Shox Headphones, Jakob Ingebrigtsen's race plans and recent fatherhood, and Justin Knight's decision to shut down his season. episodes.description: “The biggest learning experience was definitely Worlds. I feel like the other races are races I’ve done a lot before and I know how they go. Worlds was something I’ve only really done one other time. A big thing I wanted to take away from Worlds was just framing my mindset in a way that’s ‘You are as good as you think you are. You just have to go out there and act like it.’ … I gained a lot of success really quickly so it’s been a bit surprising. I’m trying to focus on who I am as a runner and where I’m supposed to be in a race.” Yared Nuguse, the American record holder in the mile, claimed his first global championship medal with a runner-up finish for silver in the 3000m at the World Indoor Championships in Glasgow last month. Nuguse will open up his 2024 outdoor campaign with the mile at the Penn Relays. He was also announced as one of the headliners for the Bowerman Mile at the Prefontaine Classic in Eugene, Oregon on May 25th.  The former Notre Dame star is considered one of the favorites to represent the United States at the 2024 Olympics in Paris. He qualified for the Tokyo Olympics with a third place finish at the 2021 U.S. Olympic Trials. However, he scratched from the race while in Tokyo due to a quad injury during his warmup. In this conversation, Mac Fleet sits down to recap his 2024 indoor season and how he’s taking lessons from competing at two global championships to work in his favor come the Trials and Summer Games. episodes.description: "You have to measure out your peaks, especially in an Olympic year. But I'm really happy with my fitness right now. In years past, I haven't been this confident in my fitness. So I'm really happy and just excited to race (against) the world champs, the American record holders. That's really where I see myself thriving and I want to optimize those opportunities." – Cole Hocker Former Oregon Ducks Cooper Teare and Cole Hocker have reunited and are training together in Blacksburg, Virginia under coach Ben Thomas. Teare spent last year working with coach Jerry Schumacher and the Bowerman Track Club before announcing his departure in the fall. He took some time to make a decision but ultimately decided to reunite with his college coach, who led him to his U.S. 1500m title in 2022 and qualified for the World Championship team. Last year, Teare did set a personal best at 800 meters and 1500m but he missed qualifying for the World Championships in Budapest. He got off to a strong start in 2024 by winning the U.S. cross country title just two weeks ago. For Hocker, he’s just elevating his training under Thomas and is hoping to have a full healthy year in the leadup to the World Indoor Championships in March and then the U.S. Olympic Trials this summer. Last year, he got off to a later start to the season due to injuries but still managed to qualify for Worlds and then finished seventh in Budapest in a personal best of 3:30.70 for 1500 meters. Both guys have been added to the men’s two-mile field at the Millrose Games on February 11th in New York City. The field includes 1500m world champion Josh Kerr and U.S. 5000m and 10,000m record holder Grant Fisher. The Millrose Games is the sixth stop on the 2024 ⁠World Athletics Indoor Tour⁠ Gold calendar. Livestream and television broadcast details will be announced in the coming weeks. Stay tuned for more Millrose Games athlete announcements as the pro fields come together. Tickets to the 116th Millrose Games can be purchased online at ⁠millrosegames.org⁠. episodes.description: CITIUS MAG's Anderson Emerole reports from Glasgow, Scotland with a recap of Day 3 of the World Indoor Championships. – Team USA earned FOUR medals in the 1500m as New Zealand's George Beamish and Ethiopia's Freweyni Hailu came away with victories but Nikki Hiltz, Emily Mackay, Cole Hocker and Hobbs Kessler all came away with medals. – Bryce Hoppel clocked a world-leading 1:44.92 to improve upon his bronze medal from 2022 to win gold in the 800m final. Ethiopia's Tsige Duguma claimed gold in the 800 – just ahead of Team GB's Jemma Reekie. – Tara Davis-Woodhall and Monae Nichols went 1-2 in the women's long jump.  – Bahamian Devynne Charlton broke her own 60m hurdles world record to claim her country's first-ever gold medal in the 800m – There was controversy over Noah Lyles being named to the 4x400m relay team and then they came away with a silver medal as Belgium's Alexander Doom kicked down Team USA in the closing meters. Lyles split 45.68, which was the third-fastest of the American team. – Mondo Duplantis claimed yet another gold in the men's pole vault. + more  🔜 We'll be sharing Anderson's daily recaps and dispatches from Scotland on the ⁠⁠⁠CITIUS MAG Podcast feed⁠⁠⁠ and ⁠⁠⁠YouTube channel⁠⁠⁠.  Keep tabs on the CITIUS MAG YouTube channel as we have tons of interviews from the mixed zone there. We'll be sharing live updates on ⁠⁠⁠Twitter/X⁠⁠⁠; ⁠⁠⁠Instagram⁠⁠⁠ and ⁠⁠⁠Threads⁠⁠⁠ all throughout the weekend.
episodes.html_description:
CITIUS MAG's Anderson Emerole reports from Glasgow, Scotland with a recap of Day 3 of the World Indoor Championships.


– Team USA earned FOUR medals in the 1500m as New Zealand's George Beamish and Ethiopia's Freweyni Hailu came away with victories but Nikki Hiltz, Emily Mackay, Cole Hocker and Hobbs Kessler all came away with medals.


– Bryce Hoppel clocked a world-leading 1:44.92 to improve upon his bronze medal from 2022 to win gold in the 800m final. Ethiopia's Tsige Duguma claimed gold in the 800 – just ahead of Team GB's Jemma Reekie.


– Tara Davis-Woodhall and Monae Nichols went 1-2 in the women's long jump.


– Bahamian Devynne Charlton broke her own 60m hurdles world record to claim her country's first-ever gold medal in the 800m


– There was controversy over Noah Lyles being named to the 4x400m relay team and then they came away with a silver medal as Belgium's Alexander Doom kicked down Team USA in the closing meters. Lyles split 45.68, which was the third-fastest of the American team.


– Mondo Duplantis claimed yet another gold in the men's pole vault.


+ more


🔜 We'll be sharing Anderson's daily recaps and dispatches from Scotland on the ⁠⁠⁠CITIUS MAG Podcast feed⁠⁠⁠ and ⁠⁠⁠YouTube channel⁠⁠⁠.


Keep tabs on the CITIUS MAG YouTube channel as we have tons of interviews from the mixed zone there. We'll be sharing live updates on ⁠⁠⁠Twitter/X⁠⁠⁠; ⁠⁠⁠Instagram⁠⁠⁠ and ⁠⁠⁠Threads⁠⁠⁠ all throughout the weekend.

episodes.name: TRIALS TALK DAY 4 (FT. MATT CENTROWITZ): COLE HOCKER BEATS YARED NUGUSE, NIA AKINS PREVAILS IN 800M (ATHING FALLS); PHOTO FINISH ELLE ST. PIERRE/ELISE CRANNY + THE QUINCY WILSON SHOW FINALE

episodes.description: “The biggest learning experience was definitely Worlds. I feel like the other races are races I’ve done a lot before and I know how they go. Worlds was something I’ve only really done one other time. A big thing I wanted to take away from Worlds was just framing my mindset in a way that’s ‘You are as good as you think you are. You just have to go out there and act like it.’ … I gained a lot of success really quickly so it’s been a bit surprising. I’m trying to focus on who I am as a runner and where I’m supposed to be in a race.” Yared Nuguse, the American record holder in the mile, claimed his first global championship medal with a runner-up finish for silver in the 3000m at the World Indoor Championships in Glasgow last month. Nuguse will open up his 2024 outdoor campaign with the mile at the Penn Relays. He was also announced as one of the headliners for the Bowerman Mile at the Prefontaine Classic in Eugene, Oregon on May 25th.  The former Notre Dame star is considered one of the favorites to represent the United States at the 2024 Olympics in Paris. He qualified for the Tokyo Olympics with a third place finish at the 2021 U.S. Olympic Trials. However, he scratched from the race while in Tokyo due to a quad injury during his warmup. In this conversation, Mac Fleet sits down to recap his 2024 indoor season and how he’s taking lessons from competing at two global championships to work in his favor come the Trials and Summer Games. episodes.html_description:
“The biggest learning experience was definitely Worlds. I feel like the other races are races I’ve done a lot before and I know how they go. Worlds was something I’ve only really done one other time. A big thing I wanted to take away from Worlds was just framing my mindset in a way that’s ‘You are as good as you think you are. You just have to go out there and act like it.’ … I gained a lot of success really quickly so it’s been a bit surprising. I’m trying to focus on who I am as a runner and where I’m supposed to be in a race.”


Yared Nuguse, the American record holder in the mile, claimed his first global championship medal with a runner-up finish for silver in the 3000m at the World Indoor Championships in Glasgow last month.


Nuguse will open up his 2024 outdoor campaign with the mile at the Penn Relays. He was also announced as one of the headliners for the Bowerman Mile at the Prefontaine Classic in Eugene, Oregon on May 25th. 


The former Notre Dame star is considered one of the favorites to represent the United States at the 2024 Olympics in Paris. He qualified for the Tokyo Olympics with a third place finish at the 2021 U.S. Olympic Trials. However, he scratched from the race while in Tokyo due to a quad injury during his warmup.


In this conversation, Mac Fleet sits down to recap his 2024 indoor season and how he’s taking lessons from competing at two global championships to work in his favor come the Trials and Summer Games.

episodes.html_description:
Chris Chavez survived his bachelor party for a track-free weekend as Anderson Emerole updates him on his highlights from the 2024 Penn Relays + takeaways from the Shanghai Diamond League.


PENN RELAYS


– 16-year-old Quincy Wilson split 44s on the high school boys' 4x400m relay twice and put his Bullis Academy (MD) team in contention against some of the top Jamaican squads.


– Harvard's women's team clocked the fastest collegiate DMR in history with a 10:37.55 to win the Championship of America and were anchored in 4:21 by Maia Ramsden.


– Villanova's men destroyed the NCAA 4 x mile record of 16:03.24 by Oregon's 2009 squad as they led two other schools under 16:00. The Wildcats won in 15:51.91 capped by a 3:54.32 anchor from Liam Murphy.


– Yared Nuguse opened up his outdoor season with a 3:51.06 mile victory and tried to get his teammate Olli Hoare under the Olympic standard but he finished in 3:51.28.


SHANGHAI DIAMOND LEAGUE


– South Africa's Akani Simbine beat Christian Coleman and Fred Kerley in 10.01.


– Great Britain's Daryll Neita won the women's 200m in 22.62 as Sha'Carri Richardson finished third in 23.11.


– Kenya's Beatrice Chepkoech won the women's steeplechase in 9:07.36. Emma Coburn dropped out with 1000m remaining due to a ankle tweak. Gabbi Jennings notched a 9:19.39 personal best for fifth place.


+ more takeaways here https://citiusmag.com/articles/shanghai-diamond-league-key-takeaways


Alexis Ohanian Introduces the 776 Invitational This September


Olympic bronze medalist Gabby Thomas and Alexis Ohanian, the Reddit co-founder who now heads the venture capital firm 776, have announced plans for the 776 Invitational – a women’s-only track event in September. Read more about it here: https://citiusmag.com/articles/gabby-thomas-reddit-founder-alexis-ohanini-776-invitational

episodes.description: "For the longest time, my definition of mental toughness was being in the call room and not being scared and not being nervous. As I get older, I think mental toughness or mental resilience is being scared, being nervous, but knowing you're mentally robust and that you can handle these stressful situations. And trusting your fitness is there, trusting yourself and your instincts, that all the pieces are there and it's not going to fail. It's okay to be nervous." It's been almost three years since Hobbs Kessler joined the CITIUS MAG Podcast. Back in 2021, he was a high school phenom out of Michigan before turning pro ahead of the 2021 U.S. Olympic Trials. Now, he's the world champion and world record holder in the road mile. We caught up just two days after he ran 3:48.86 to finish second in the Wanamaker Mile at the Millrose Games to become the second-fastest American man in history. In this episode, he opens up about his training and adjustments he's made – including not running any run longer than seven miles, doubling every day and still sharpening his speed. Hobbs also shares how he's changed in his approach to racing and feels that he belongs among the best pros. Time Stamps: 4:39 - Recalling his first summer as a pro. 5:15 - His confidence before becoming an established pro.  6:23 - Some of the low points he’s experienced over the past two years. 8:16 - The people that have had the greatest impact on him.  9:07 - His training and mindset leading into the 2024 indoor season.  11:33 - What training in Flagstaff looked like for him in January.  13:57 - His training philosophy + finding what training works best for him. 17:50 - Experimenting with training.  18:31 - Breaking down his training structure.  20:19 - How he’s been able to continue developing speed. 24:13 - Race tactics and strategy.  26:08 - Goals heading into the Millrose Games Wanamaker Mile.  27:50 - Thoughts leading into Indoor USAs.  29:02 - Where his current fitness is at.  31:12 - Thoughts on the BU track.  32:20 - His favorite race. 33:45 - What race he would re-run if he could do it over 35:01 - Advice on managing nerves before racing. episodes.description: "We're here to medal. We worked so hard and no one worked harder than any of us. You just have to do it on the day. I think we all did it and it's so cool – obviously, it's indoors and sure there's an asterisk because it's not the Olympics or World Outdoor Champs, but it's a race when it matters. It's a championship. There are medals on the line and we are so competitive. We're going to run fearless. We're going to be like Hobbs Kessler, who is 20 years old and led that whole thing or Emily (Mackay) in her first world champs and she's like, 'F**k it. I'm just going to take the lead.' We're going to make bold moves. We're gonna be really hard to beat. And I think that's the momentum we're taking into outdoors. That's a statement we're making." This is Nikki Hiltz's fifth time on the show. Our last interviews came after last summer’s World Championships in Budapest and also after they broke the U.S. outdoor mile record at the Monaco Diamond League. The hot streak has continued into 2024. Last month, Hiltz won the U.S. Indoor Championships for the second consecutive season. And just this past weekend, they ran two personal bests at the World Indoor Championships to earn a silver medal in the 1500m final. Ethiopia’s Freweyi Hailu earned gold in 4:01.46. Hiltz came in less than a second behind her for the third-fastest indoor 1500m performance in U.S. history. Team New Balance Boston’s Emily Mackay finished third for bronze. The U.S. had a super strong showing at the World Indoor Championships. We topped the medal table with 20 total medals. Seven of those medals came in middle distance events – including four in the 1500m between Hiltz, Mackay, Cole Hocker and Hobbs Kessler. In this episode, Nikki recaps their whole trip to Glasgow, the learnings from another World Championship experience, the statement made by American middle distance runners and how their outlook shifts to the outdoor season now. episodes.description: CITIUS MAG's Anderson Emerole reports from Glasgow, Scotland with a recap of Day 3 of the World Indoor Championships. – Team USA earned FOUR medals in the 1500m as New Zealand's George Beamish and Ethiopia's Freweyni Hailu came away with victories but Nikki Hiltz, Emily Mackay, Cole Hocker and Hobbs Kessler all came away with medals. – Bryce Hoppel clocked a world-leading 1:44.92 to improve upon his bronze medal from 2022 to win gold in the 800m final. Ethiopia's Tsige Duguma claimed gold in the 800 – just ahead of Team GB's Jemma Reekie. – Tara Davis-Woodhall and Monae Nichols went 1-2 in the women's long jump.  – Bahamian Devynne Charlton broke her own 60m hurdles world record to claim her country's first-ever gold medal in the 800m – There was controversy over Noah Lyles being named to the 4x400m relay team and then they came away with a silver medal as Belgium's Alexander Doom kicked down Team USA in the closing meters. Lyles split 45.68, which was the third-fastest of the American team. – Mondo Duplantis claimed yet another gold in the men's pole vault. + more  🔜 We'll be sharing Anderson's daily recaps and dispatches from Scotland on the ⁠⁠⁠CITIUS MAG Podcast feed⁠⁠⁠ and ⁠⁠⁠YouTube channel⁠⁠⁠.  Keep tabs on the CITIUS MAG YouTube channel as we have tons of interviews from the mixed zone there. We'll be sharing live updates on ⁠⁠⁠Twitter/X⁠⁠⁠; ⁠⁠⁠Instagram⁠⁠⁠ and ⁠⁠⁠Threads⁠⁠⁠ all throughout the weekend.
episodes.html_description:
CITIUS MAG's Anderson Emerole reports from Glasgow, Scotland with a recap of Day 3 of the World Indoor Championships.


– Team USA earned FOUR medals in the 1500m as New Zealand's George Beamish and Ethiopia's Freweyni Hailu came away with victories but Nikki Hiltz, Emily Mackay, Cole Hocker and Hobbs Kessler all came away with medals.


– Bryce Hoppel clocked a world-leading 1:44.92 to improve upon his bronze medal from 2022 to win gold in the 800m final. Ethiopia's Tsige Duguma claimed gold in the 800 – just ahead of Team GB's Jemma Reekie.


– Tara Davis-Woodhall and Monae Nichols went 1-2 in the women's long jump.


– Bahamian Devynne Charlton broke her own 60m hurdles world record to claim her country's first-ever gold medal in the 800m


– There was controversy over Noah Lyles being named to the 4x400m relay team and then they came away with a silver medal as Belgium's Alexander Doom kicked down Team USA in the closing meters. Lyles split 45.68, which was the third-fastest of the American team.


– Mondo Duplantis claimed yet another gold in the men's pole vault.


+ more


🔜 We'll be sharing Anderson's daily recaps and dispatches from Scotland on the ⁠⁠⁠CITIUS MAG Podcast feed⁠⁠⁠ and ⁠⁠⁠YouTube channel⁠⁠⁠.


Keep tabs on the CITIUS MAG YouTube channel as we have tons of interviews from the mixed zone there. We'll be sharing live updates on ⁠⁠⁠Twitter/X⁠⁠⁠; ⁠⁠⁠Instagram⁠⁠⁠ and ⁠⁠⁠Threads⁠⁠⁠ all throughout the weekend.

episodes.description: E' un positivo botta e risposta quello del primato italiano sui 1500 metri al coperto. Sabato 27 febbraio Pietro Arese lo porta a 3:37.03 e dopo solo cinque giorni Federico Riva lo abbassa a 3:36.74. Il giorno dopo il primato riprende la firma di Ossama Meslek che a Metz ferma il cronometro su 3.36.04. Poi qualche ora dopo, sempre a Metz, Pietro Arese mette la sua firma sul record italiano dei 3000 metri al coperto, 7:38.42. Togliendo, dopo 27 anni, il primato a Gennaro Di Napoli (7:41.05 nel 1997 a Parigi).Un fermento tra 1500 e 3000 metri che proiettano, il nostro ospite di oggi, Pietro Arese ai prossimi appuntamenti stagionali. Tra tutti l'Europeo di atletica a Roma, 7-12 giugno e ovviamente le olimpiadi di Parigi, 1-11 agosto 2024.Nella seconda parte il coach Fabio Vedana risponde alle domande degli ascoltatori in tema di corsa, triathlon e allenamento.Crediti foto: Atl-Eticamente Foto / FIDAL Veneto
episodes.html_description:
E' un positivo botta e risposta quello del primato italiano sui 1500 metri al coperto. Sabato 27 febbraio Pietro Arese lo porta a 3:37.03 e dopo solo cinque giorni Federico Riva lo abbassa a 3:36.74. Il giorno dopo il primato riprende la firma di Ossama Meslek che a Metz ferma il cronometro su 3.36.04. Poi qualche ora dopo, sempre a Metz, Pietro Arese mette la sua firma sul record italiano dei 3000 metri al coperto, 7:38.42. Togliendo, dopo 27 anni, il primato a Gennaro Di Napoli (7:41.05 nel 1997 a Parigi).

Un fermento tra 1500 e 3000 metri che proiettano, il nostro ospite di oggi, Pietro Arese ai prossimi appuntamenti stagionali. Tra tutti l'Europeo di atletica a Roma, 7-12 giugno e ovviamente le olimpiadi di Parigi, 1-11 agosto 2024.

Nella seconda parte il coach Fabio Vedana risponde alle domande degli ascoltatori in tema di corsa, triathlon e allenamento.
Crediti foto: Atl-Eticamente Foto / FIDAL Veneto

episodes.description: "You have to measure out your peaks, especially in an Olympic year. But I'm really happy with my fitness right now. In years past, I haven't been this confident in my fitness. So I'm really happy and just excited to race (against) the world champs, the American record holders. That's really where I see myself thriving and I want to optimize those opportunities." – Cole Hocker Former Oregon Ducks Cooper Teare and Cole Hocker have reunited and are training together in Blacksburg, Virginia under coach Ben Thomas. Teare spent last year working with coach Jerry Schumacher and the Bowerman Track Club before announcing his departure in the fall. He took some time to make a decision but ultimately decided to reunite with his college coach, who led him to his U.S. 1500m title in 2022 and qualified for the World Championship team. Last year, Teare did set a personal best at 800 meters and 1500m but he missed qualifying for the World Championships in Budapest. He got off to a strong start in 2024 by winning the U.S. cross country title just two weeks ago. For Hocker, he’s just elevating his training under Thomas and is hoping to have a full healthy year in the leadup to the World Indoor Championships in March and then the U.S. Olympic Trials this summer. Last year, he got off to a later start to the season due to injuries but still managed to qualify for Worlds and then finished seventh in Budapest in a personal best of 3:30.70 for 1500 meters. Both guys have been added to the men’s two-mile field at the Millrose Games on February 11th in New York City. The field includes 1500m world champion Josh Kerr and U.S. 5000m and 10,000m record holder Grant Fisher. The Millrose Games is the sixth stop on the 2024 ⁠World Athletics Indoor Tour⁠ Gold calendar. Livestream and television broadcast details will be announced in the coming weeks. Stay tuned for more Millrose Games athlete announcements as the pro fields come together. Tickets to the 116th Millrose Games can be purchased online at ⁠millrosegames.org⁠. episodes.description: Wir haben zuletzt so oft davon gesprochen kein "Mitteldistanz-Podcast" zu sein, dass es einfach nur konsequent ist sich heute mit der Mittelstrecke zu befassen. Genauer gesagt mit 800 bzw. 1500 Metern und dem Mann, der auf dieser Distanz schon Deutscher Meister war: Robert Farken. Oder wie der Lange sagt: Hat was drauf, kann schnell rennen und sieht auch noch gut aus. Das lassen wir mal wirken. Obwohl er initial seine Zeit dem Runden - das ins Eckige muss - gewidmet hat, ist er letztlich auf der Bahn gelandet - und im Stadion geblieben. Finden wir gut, denn dort wo Robert herkommt gäbe es sowieso nur Brause-Ballsport, oder dritte Liga. Dann doch lieber laufen. Natürlich spricht Simon auch Roberts großes Hobby, schwarz-weiße Instabilder, an, und die beiden unterhalten sich über alles, was halt so dazugehört, wenn man sich so selten sieht. In jedem Fall: Schön, dass du da warst Robert. Und für euch da draußen: Zieht euch mal die Laufschuhe an, nicht immer nur Podcast, Podcast, Podcast. Dann wird das auch was, bis Silvester.

episodes.html_description:
Chris Chavez and Anderson Emerole unpack the first big weekend in track and field as the Diamond League and Continental Tour kicked off.


In this week's round-up of performances, they discuss:


Xiamen Diamond League


– Mondo Duplantis’ 6.24m world record and what it could mean for the rest of the season


– Gudaf Tsegay nearly breaks the 1500m world record with a 3:50.30; Did the women’s 1500m suddenly get more interesting?


– Torrie Lewis beats Sha’Carri Richardson in the 200m; Is there reason to be concerned?


– Marco Arop vs. Emmanuel Wanyonyi needs to be a thing to bring back the men's 800m to prominence


– Is the U.S. having a moment in the men’s high jump? Shelby McEwen wins in Xiamen, JuVaughn Harrison jumps a world lead at LSU


– Paulino wins 400m and says this may be the year to break the 400m World record


– Christian Coleman wins the 100m in only 10.13s ahead of Fred Kerley; another slow year for the 100m?


Results from around the world


– Courtney Lindsey beat Letsile Tebogo in a 200m at the Kip Keino Classic


– Gabby Thomas ran 50.37 at LSU


– Christine Mboma, competing for the first time since August 2022, runs 12.32 and finishes last in the women's 100 at the Kip Keino Classic


– Mary Moraa opened up her 2024 800m campaign with a 1:57.96 at the Kip Keino Classic


– 17-year-old Christian Miller drops a 9.93 for 100m at a small meet in Clermont, Florida to take the world lead and break the U.S. U20 record.


London Marathon


– Peres Jepchirchir breaks the women’s-only marathon record In 2:16:16


– Alexander Mutiso Munyao wins his first Major in 2:04:01


– Kenenisa Bekele smashes his own Masters record In 2:04:15


– So who is the Kenyan Olympic marathon team?

episodes.description: Canadian distance runner Ben Flanagan joins host David Stol to break down his most recent race at the John Thomas Terrier Classic, where he walked away with an Olympic standard time in the 5000m with a personal best of 13:04:62.We also discuss his training leading up to the race, what lies ahead on his road towards the Paris Olympics, fellow Canadian Marco Arop's record-breaking performance the following day, and more.Subscribe to The Shakeout Podcast feed on Apple, Spotify, SoundCloud, or wherever you find your podcasts and follow @canadianrunning and @shakeoutpodcast for more storytelling from the running world.

episodes.description: "I never had any problems with the workouts, but for me personally, I think it started to affect my mental and social side to where my relationship with running wasn't really happy. There was almost a nonexistent excitement for workouts and I was just kind of going through the monotony, but not enjoying it. And so changing it up, when you need excitement to love running again – being with VNTC guys lit that spark for me again. I am getting better at physical training and it's exciting with Hobbs. That guy's amazing and I just needed a new change of scenery." The kid from Midland, Texas went to the University of Kansas to chase some big dreams and now Bryce Hoppel is a World Indoor Champion. It was won with experience as much as it was with fitness. It happens in the blink of an eye that the rookie becomes the veteran, but now Hoppel is in the prime years of his career. I hadn’t yet given my congratulations to him so I reached out to hear how everything was being digested since Glasgow. episodes.html_description:
"I never had any problems with the workouts, but for me personally, I think it started to affect my mental and social side to where my relationship with running wasn't really happy. There was almost a nonexistent excitement for workouts and I was just kind of going through the monotony, but not enjoying it. And so changing it up, when you need excitement to love running again – being with VNTC guys lit that spark for me again. I am getting better at physical training and it's exciting with Hobbs. That guy's amazing and I just needed a new change of scenery."


The kid from Midland, Texas went to the University of Kansas to chase some big dreams and now Bryce Hoppel is a World Indoor Champion. It was won with experience as much as it was with fitness. It happens in the blink of an eye that the rookie becomes the veteran, but now Hoppel is in the prime years of his career. I hadn’t yet given my congratulations to him so I reached out to hear how everything was being digested since Glasgow.


Host: Kyle Merber | ⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠@kylemerber on Instagram⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠

episodes.name: Bryce Hoppel On Winning Gold In The 800m At The 2024 World Indoor Championships

episodes.description: CITIUS MAG's Anderson Emerole reports from Glasgow, Scotland with a recap of Day 3 of the World Indoor Championships. – Team USA earned FOUR medals in the 1500m as New Zealand's George Beamish and Ethiopia's Freweyni Hailu came away with victories but Nikki Hiltz, Emily Mackay, Cole Hocker and Hobbs Kessler all came away with medals. – Bryce Hoppel clocked a world-leading 1:44.92 to improve upon his bronze medal from 2022 to win gold in the 800m final. Ethiopia's Tsige Duguma claimed gold in the 800 – just ahead of Team GB's Jemma Reekie. – Tara Davis-Woodhall and Monae Nichols went 1-2 in the women's long jump.  – Bahamian Devynne Charlton broke her own 60m hurdles world record to claim her country's first-ever gold medal in the 800m – There was controversy over Noah Lyles being named to the 4x400m relay team and then they came away with a silver medal as Belgium's Alexander Doom kicked down Team USA in the closing meters. Lyles split 45.68, which was the third-fastest of the American team. – Mondo Duplantis claimed yet another gold in the men's pole vault. + more  🔜 We'll be sharing Anderson's daily recaps and dispatches from Scotland on the ⁠⁠⁠CITIUS MAG Podcast feed⁠⁠⁠ and ⁠⁠⁠YouTube channel⁠⁠⁠.  Keep tabs on the CITIUS MAG YouTube channel as we have tons of interviews from the mixed zone there. We'll be sharing live updates on ⁠⁠⁠Twitter/X⁠⁠⁠; ⁠⁠⁠Instagram⁠⁠⁠ and ⁠⁠⁠Threads⁠⁠⁠ all throughout the weekend.
episodes.html_description:
CITIUS MAG's Anderson Emerole reports from Glasgow, Scotland with a recap of Day 3 of the World Indoor Championships.


– Team USA earned FOUR medals in the 1500m as New Zealand's George Beamish and Ethiopia's Freweyni Hailu came away with victories but Nikki Hiltz, Emily Mackay, Cole Hocker and Hobbs Kessler all came away with medals.


– Bryce Hoppel clocked a world-leading 1:44.92 to improve upon his bronze medal from 2022 to win gold in the 800m final. Ethiopia's Tsige Duguma claimed gold in the 800 – just ahead of Team GB's Jemma Reekie.


– Tara Davis-Woodhall and Monae Nichols went 1-2 in the women's long jump.


– Bahamian Devynne Charlton broke her own 60m hurdles world record to claim her country's first-ever gold medal in the 800m


– There was controversy over Noah Lyles being named to the 4x400m relay team and then they came away with a silver medal as Belgium's Alexander Doom kicked down Team USA in the closing meters. Lyles split 45.68, which was the third-fastest of the American team.


– Mondo Duplantis claimed yet another gold in the men's pole vault.


+ more


🔜 We'll be sharing Anderson's daily recaps and dispatches from Scotland on the ⁠⁠⁠CITIUS MAG Podcast feed⁠⁠⁠ and ⁠⁠⁠YouTube channel⁠⁠⁠.


Keep tabs on the CITIUS MAG YouTube channel as we have tons of interviews from the mixed zone there. We'll be sharing live updates on ⁠⁠⁠Twitter/X⁠⁠⁠; ⁠⁠⁠Instagram⁠⁠⁠ and ⁠⁠⁠Threads⁠⁠⁠ all throughout the weekend.
episodes.name: World Indoor Championships Day 3 Recap: United States Wins 11 Medals on Final Day (Bryce Hoppel! Tara Davis-Woodhall! Nikki Hiltz! Cole Hocker! Emily Mackay! Hobbs Kessler! + More)

episodes.description: It's a jam packed ultimate recap episode! We kick it off with an indepth discussion about World Athletic's Ultimate Championships and its impact on the sports. We cover New York City Grand Prix with Sage Hurta-Klecker's big W and Eric Holt's duel with Jake Wightman. We also talk a bit about Fred Kerley's big day and Sydney Mclaughlin's impressive open 400m as well. We jump into some NCAA Championship recap including the men and women's distance events and also get into the European Champs a bit. We live react to Jakob Ingebrigtsen's 1500m and earning a triple double gold. episodes.description: Jake Wightman is off and running with his guide service Wightman Outdoors. Jake is a dedicated hunter with years under his belt guiding and chasing everything from snow geese to cranes, ducks, canada geese and bear. Joey and our good buddy Paul Heigel ran out to check out his operation in South Dakota and chased snow for a few days. Jake talks about guiding for different animals and birds and his experiences growing his business. They also talk about bear hunting, cranes in MN and some snow goose snacks in the pit blind. If you’re looking for an experienced snow goose guide give Jake a shout and tell him we sent you! Thanks for listening and leave us a review!    New Waterfowl Film out now! 143 Birds in Canada! episodes.html_description:
347: The Race for Olympic Qualifiers | NSW XC Championships | Mizuno Wave Neo Vista Review


 


This episode of Inside Running Podcast is proudly brought to you by Aid Station, Australia’s and New Zealand’s leading online store for all things endurance sports nutrition and accessories, head over to www.aidstation.com.au


 


Julian pulls up sore from last week’s trail half marathon win.

Brad has an injury scare as the Gold Coast Marathon draws closer.

Brady puts in a big week ahead of his pacing job at Gold Coast Marathon.


 


Izzy Batt-Doyle runs the fourth fastest of all time and an Olympic qualifier of 14:49.75 in the 5000m at d’Athletisme Province Liege in Belgium. Nat Rule was also in the 5000m running 15:13.42, while Ed Trippas posted a 8:38.85 in the 3000m steeplechase and Jesse Hunt ran 3:37.88 in the 1500m.

Results


 


Peyton Craig runs 3rd all-time fastest 800m of 1:44.12 at the On Track Nights in Vienna, Austria with Joseph Deng 1:46.41, while Jenny Blundell 14:59.84 5000m for the 7th fastest of all time, with Holly Campbell running 15:09.92, Maudie Skyring in 15:16.56, Leanne Pompeani in 15:22.95, Paige Campbell in 15:42.23 and Olga Firsova 16:15.29.

Bendere Oboya ran a lifetime best 1:58.56 in the 800m, with Claudia Hollingsworth running 2:00.02 and Jaylah Hancock-Cameron in 2:02.03.

In the Men’s 5000m, Ky Robinson ran 13:22.81 and Jackson Sharp 13:25.87.

On Track Nights Vienna Results


 


Ben Buckingham posted an 8:21.34 in the 3000m steeplechase at the Paavo Nurmi Games in Finland. Catriona Bisset ran 2:00.61 and Claudia Hollingsworth a 2:01.36 in the 800m while Adam Spencer set a 3:43.55 in the 1500m.

Results via World Athletics


 


Bendere Oboya runs 600m National Record of 1:24.53 in Bilbao Spain while Matt Clarke ran personal best of 8:20.06 in the 3000m Steeplechase.

Results via World Athletics


 


Linden Hall ran 3:58.96 in the 1500m in Bydgoszcz, Poland coming second, ahead of Sarah Billings in 4:00.45 and Abbey Caldwell in 4:05.45. Cameron Myers ran 3:38.55 in his 1500m.

Results via World Athletics


 


NSW XC Championships held at Willandra won by Ed Goddard in 31:47 over 10km, ahead Luke Hince and Ben St Lawrence. Kate Spencer topped the podium in the women’s 10k race in 36:41, followed by Danette Sheehan and Laura Simon

Results


 


Grant Fisher takes 10000m in the first week of the US Olympic Trials, with his soon to be teammates Woody Kincaid and Nico Young

USATF Results


 


Mizuno have released their highly anticipated Wave Neo Vista and the boys finally get to talk about how they’ve been using it, what its specs are as well as what it compares to the super trainer category.


 


Listener Question asks what to do when you get sick right around raceday, then Moose goes Loose on the financial barrier to entry for the casual athletics fan.


Patreon Link: https://www.patreon.com/insiderunningpodcast


Opening and Closing Music is Undercover of my Skin by Benny Walker. www.bennywalkermusic.com


Join the conversation at: https://www.facebook.com/insiderunningpodcast/


To donate and show your support for the show: https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_s-xclick&hosted_button_id=9K9WQCZNA2KAN

episodes.description: We got one of the league’s young studs in the building this week. The number two pick in last year’s draft, the Hornets’ own Brandon Miller joins Q and D this week on Knuckleheads. The trio takes a look back at Brandon as a three-sport athlete, checking the stats on his pitching and quarterbacking résumés. Brandon discusses his rise during high school and how he considered going overseas instead of to college, as well as just how he dominated at Bama. He also gets into how he feels his rookie year went — and, of course, we got LaMelo stories. Tune in!   Growing up a three-sport athlete in Tennessee, being a 6’7” punter (3:45) First time he beat his brother in 1-on-1 (6:26)  Playing for Bradley Beal’s AAU team (9:29)  Almost going overseas, electing to go to Alabama for college (21:06) Draft process, getting picked No. 2 by the Hornets and meeting LaMelo (34:05) First time meeting MJ (35:33) Brandon’s car collection (47:27)  About Our Hosts: NBA veterans Quentin Richardson and Darius Miles are lifelong friends and bona fide truth-tellers. Listen as they invite special guests, high-profile athletes, musicians and entertainers to get brutally honest about everything from current events to untold stories from the golden era of sports and culture. Named for the on-court celebration they made wildly popular, this unfiltered, hilarious and surprising podcast is like playing NBA 2K with no fouls. Other places to find Knuckleheads:  Subscribe on Youtube Follow on Instagram Follow on FacebookSee omnystudio.com/listener for privacy information.
episodes.html_description:
We got one of the league’s young studs in the building this week. The number two pick in last year’s draft, the Hornets’ own Brandon Miller joins Q and D this week on Knuckleheads. The trio takes a look back at Brandon as a three-sport athlete, checking the stats on his pitching and quarterbacking résumés. Brandon discusses his rise during high school and how he considered going overseas instead of to college, as well as just how he dominated at Bama. He also gets into how he feels his rookie year went — and, of course, we got LaMelo stories. Tune in! 

  1. Growing up a three-sport athlete in Tennessee, being a 6’7” punter (3:45)
  2. First time he beat his brother in 1-on-1 (6:26) 
  3. Playing for Bradley Beal’s AAU team (9:29) 
  4. Almost going overseas, electing to go to Alabama for college (21:06)
  5. Draft process, getting picked No. 2 by the Hornets and meeting LaMelo (34:05)
  6. First time meeting MJ (35:33)
  7. Brandon’s car collection (47:27)

About Our Hosts:

NBA veterans Quentin Richardson and Darius Miles are lifelong friends and bona fide truth-tellers. Listen as they invite special guests, high-profile athletes, musicians and entertainers to get brutally honest about everything from current events to untold stories from the golden era of sports and culture. Named for the on-court celebration they made wildly popular, this unfiltered, hilarious and surprising podcast is like playing NBA 2K with no fouls.

episodes.description: Beau Martonik is joined by Brandon Miller of the Everyday Outdoorsmen. Brandon is an avid Pennsylvania hunter who spends every weekend he can in the woods. They discuss Brandon’s YouTube channel, his 2023 deer hunting season, a still-hunting strategy that works really well, different methods for getting a deer out of the woods, mountain laurel bedding, deer camp, hunting in September in Maryland, building his own traditional bow, and much more! episodes.description: Eliott Crestan a décroché le bronze sur 800m aux mondiaux en salle de Glasgow début mars. C’est sa troisième médaille de bronze internationale, après celles remportées aux mondiaux juniors de 2018 et aux "Europe" en salle de 2023. Eliott est également vice-champion d’Europe espoirs 2021. Dans cet épisode, Eliott revient sur son excellente saison en salle 2024, et notamment sur sa victoire à Liévin. Il nous explique ce qu’il a changé ces derniers mois dans sa préparation et nous parle également de sa relation avec André Mahy, son entraîneur de toujours, et de l’ambiance et de l’émulation au sein de l’équipe de Belgique. J’ai également demandé à Eliott ce qu’il considérerait comme une saison 2024 réussie et quels étaient ses objectifs sportifs pour cette année. Pour info, nous avons enregistré cet épisode le 14 mai 2024.Bonne écoute !Écoutez l'épisode avec David Rudisha (disponible en anglais et doublé en français)Suivez Eliott Crestan sur les réseaux sociaux :InstagramFacebookSuivez ATHLÈTES MONDIAUX : X Instagram Facebook YouTube TikTokThreadsSite Internet 👉 Soutenez le podcast via Tipeee 👈 Abonnez-vous au podcast et à la newsletter "Athlètes mondiaux".📢 Proposez-moi des invité(e)s À bientôt pour un nouvel épisode ! Et vive l'athlé ! Hébergé par Ausha. Visitez ausha.co/politique-de-confidentialite pour plus d'informations.

🌴 BERMUDA GRAND PRIX: If you’re interested in a spring getaway to a warm weather destination and want to also watch some quality track and field + get a chance to meet some of the biggest stars – ⁠the Bermuda Grand Prix⁠ has put together several packages to bring you that experience from April 26th to 29th. ⁠Spectator/Olympic Alumni Packages⁠ include round-trip airport pickup and drop-off and hotel accommodation at the Coco Reefs Resort, tickets to the opening and closing events, access to the USATF Bermuda Grand Prix 2024, ground transportation to the National Sports Centre and more. Packages start at $1,335.

episodes.description: 335: World Cross Country Championships | Albie Thomas Mile This episode is sponsored by Precision Fuel & Hydration, check out their free online planner that you can use to work out how much carb, sodium and fluid you need to perform at your best.  Click here then use the code at checkout as mentioned on the show for a discount.  Brad gets in more mileage as he prepares to sell his house. Julian continues to manage his knee while discovering Pia’s competitive streak. Brady recovers from sickness as the Ballarat Marathon draws near.   Jacob Kiplimo of Uganda defends his title at World Cross Country Championships in Belgrade, Serbia, ahead of Berihu Aregawi of Ethiopia and Benson Kiplangat of Kenya. In the team medals, Team Kenya took home the gold medal with a team score of 19, with Uganda winning silver and Ethiopia the bronze. Australian men’s team placed 5th overall, as the placings follow:   Haftu Strintzos 23rd   Ed Marks 24th   Liam Adams 29th   Pat Tiernan 30th   Andre Waring (46th)    Zach Facioni (51st)    Beatrice Chebet also won back to back titles, leading a Kenyan clean sweep with Lillian Rengeruk taking the silver medal and Margaret Kipkemboi the bronze. Kenya thus won the team title with the lowest possible score of 10 points, ahead of Ethiopia in second and Uganda in third. Paige Campbell was the top Australian in 31st place, with Melissa Duncan persevering in 53rd. World Cross Country Championships Full Results https://www.instagram.com/p/C5JCOOyOUhM/    Abbey Caldwell won the Australian Mile Championship at the Albie Thomas Mile at The Crest, Bankstown running 4:30.50 ahead of Lauren Ryan and Maudie Skyring. Jesse Hunt won the Men’s Mile Championship in 3:59.09, outlasting Jack Anstey and Riley Bryce. Luke Boyes carried his momentum to win the 800m ahead of Peter Bol and Cameron Myers, while Jess Hull won the Women’s A 800m in 2:03.02 ahead of Imogen Barrett and Bendere Oboya. Albie Thomas Results   Adam Spencer ran 1:47.47 to win the 800m at Stanford Invitational, while Ky Robinson ran 13:35.95 in the 5000m, then followed up running 28:15.12 in the 10000m. Report via Go Stanford    Listener Question asks how to balance training and raising children, then Moose previews Precision Fuel & Hydration event coming to The Running Company Geelong. Patreon Link: https://www.patreon.com/insiderunningpodcast Opening and Closing Music is Undercover of my Skin by Benny Walker. www.bennywalkermusic.com Join the conversation at: https://www.facebook.com/insiderunningpodcast/ To donate and show your support for the show: https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_s-xclick&hosted_button_id=9K9WQCZNA2KAN

Jacob Kiplimo of Uganda defends his title at World Cross Country Championships in Belgrade, Serbia, ahead of Berihu Aregawi of Ethiopia and Benson Kiplangat of Kenya. Beatrice Chebet also won back to back titles, leading a Kenyan clean sweep with Lillian Rengeruk taking the silver medal and Margaret Kipkemboi the bronze. Kenya thus won the team title with the lowest possible score of 10 points, ahead of Ethiopia in second and Uganda in third.


Paige Campbell was the top Australian in 31st place, with Melissa Duncan persevering in 53rd.


World Cross Country Championships Full Results

https://www.instagram.com/p/C5JCOOyOUhM/ 


 


Abbey Caldwell won the Australian Mile Championship at the Albie Thomas Mile at The Crest, Bankstown running 4:30.50 ahead of Lauren Ryan and Maudie Skyring. Jesse Hunt won the Men’s Mile Championship in 3:59.09, outlasting Jack Anstey and Riley Bryce.

Luke Boyes carried his momentum to win the 800m ahead of Peter Bol and Cameron Myers, while Jess Hull won the Women’s A 800m in 2:03.02 ahead of Imogen Barrett and Bendere Oboya.

Albie Thomas Results


 


Adam Spencer ran 1:47.47 to win the 800m at Stanford Invitational, while Ky Robinson ran 13:35.95 in the 5000m, then followed up running 28:15.12 in the 10000m.

Report via Go Stanford 


 


Listener Question asks how to balance training and raising children, then Moose previews Precision Fuel & Hydration event coming to The Running Company Geelong.

episodes.description: I det etthundraåttioåttonde avsnittet av ”Maratonlabbet - en podcast om löpning” publiceras en färsk intervju med Sveriges bästa löpare, Andreas Almgren. Han har under våren slagit svenskt rekord på sex av sina sju starter på distanser från 3 000 meter upp till halvmaraton. I ett längre samtal reflekterar han kring rekordvåren och blickar fram mot sommarens två stora mästerskap, EM i Rom och OS i Paris. Han berättar om träningen som ska få honom i fullt slag när det väl gäller, och tror att Europarekordet på 5 000 meter kan hänga löst i höst. Under den andra halvan av avsnittet lämnar vi en ordentlig rapport från Stockholm Marathon där både Johan och Erik samt deras två adepter Thea Emilsson och Måns Andersson berättar om sina upplevelser. Följ Maratonlabbet under den sjunde säsongen för att lära er mer om löpning och för att se om Johan Forsstedt och Erik Olofsson klarar sina smala mål på 10 kilometer, halvmaraton, Lidingöloppet, maraton och ultralöpning.

episodes.description: Med Andreas Almgrens framfart de senaste åren, med svenska rekord på löpande band, kan det upplevas som en självklarthet att vår just nu starkast skinande löparstjärna skulle nå världseliten. Med den senaste tidens prestationer har Sollentunasonen fört in svensk långdistanslöpning på en scen som den tidigare aldrig skådat. Det är därför lätt att glömma att vägen dit inte varit helt självklar. I en lång intervju berättar Andreas om sina mörka löparår. Tiden då skadorna avlöste varandra och vägen till världseliten inte alls var så spikrak som den har upplevts den senaste tiden. Missa inte detta fördjupande samtal som visar på en kämparglöd och en motivation som banat väg för allt som Andreas presterar idag.  John fortsätter sin turné av mindre svenska långlopp och har besökt Hallarydsloppet i djupaste Småland. Manne börjar finna formen på ett löpband i Härjedalen. Allt går som det ska!    Veckans Sponsorer: Löplabbet (missa inte den kommande temposkoguiden) samt Saucony.

episodes.name: 226. Almgrens mörka år

episodes.description: I det etthundrasjuttiosjunde avsnittet av ”Maratonlabbet - en podcast om löpning” pratar vi med Andreas Almgren som återigen har satt ett fantastiskt svenskt rekord. Med 59:23 på Barcelona Halvmarathon slog han det svenska rekordet med nästan två minuter, det nordiska rekordet med 24 sekunder och var bara tio sekunder från Europarekordet. Hör Andreas själv berätta om loppet och förberedelserna inför. Avsnittet innehåller också en längre intervju med Mikael Ekvall som länge var Sveriges bästa maratonlöpare men som sadlade om och började satsa på ultralöpning för knappt tre år sedan. Starten på ultrakarriären blev lite knackig på grund av skada och husbygge men under fjolåret fick han till det ordentligt och med 94,45 kilometer på en 6-timmars tävling i Borås slog han både svenskt och nordiskt rekord i november. Nu är han på jakt efter Jonas Buuds svenska rekord på 100km och ser SM i Växjö som nästa stora mål. I skuggan av allt detta har även Erik börjat kunna springa mer igen efter en längre period med hälseneproblem och Johan har fått till sin största löpvecka för året. Följ Maratonlabbet under den sjunde säsongen för att lära er mer om löpning och för att se om Johan Forsstedt och Erik Olofsson klarar sina smala mål på 10 kilometer, halvmaraton, Lidingöloppet, maraton och ultralöpning.

episodes.description: 2024 rivstartar med det etthundrasjuttiofemte avsnittet av ”Maratonlabbet - en podcast om löpning” där vi intervjuar både rekordmannen Andreas Almgren och målaren från Äppelbo, Jeppe Lundberg. Andreas Almgrens 27:20 på 10km i Valencia var både svenskt och nordiskt rekord, samt den tredje bästa tiden någonsin av en europé. Hör Andreas själv berätta om loppet som gick överraskande bra även för honom trots att det fanns vissa saker att putsa på till framtiden. Han berättar också vad han tror om Barcelona Halvmarathon som han ska springa om knappt fyra veckor. Jesper ”Jeppe” Lundberg är målaren från Äppelbo som började springa 2015 och snabbt gjorde stora framsteg. Efter att ha sprungit sub2.18 i Berlin Marathon 2022 bestämde han sig för att satsa allt på löpningen 2023 och lade målarpenslar och rollers på hyllan. Hör honom berätta om vad det första året som proffs har gett honom och hur han kommer att fortsätta sin satsning. Dessutom berättar Johan och Erik om sina mål för säsongen 2024 som ska bli den bästa hittills, både löp- och poddmässigt. Erik har också uppfunnit ett nytt träningsupplägg som han kallar ”Nils Gyllebring”-metoden. Följ Maratonlabbet under den sjunde säsongen för att lära er mer om löpning och för att se om Johan Forsstedt och Erik Olofsson klarar sina smala mål på 10 kilometer, halvmaraton, Lidingöloppet, maraton och ultralöpning.

episodes.description: Josh Kerr is running World Indoors vs Yared Nuguse and Selemon Barega. Cole Hocker was sublime in the 1500m at the USATF Champs. Are Kerr and Hocker favorites for Gold in Glasgow? Noah Lyles took down Christian Coleman, what does that do to his gold medal chances? Meanwhile Letsile Tebogo broke the 300m world record. episodes.description: Hey guys, welcome back the show. In this episode we welcome a special guest, our good friend and Boulder's actual resident Aussie: Jamie Laverty! Jamie is a talented runner and a passionate fan of the sport. We dig into his love for the game but he also helps guest host today's very fun episode. We cover a bunch including Brazier's exit and Olli's coaching plan for him, Track & Field News' world rankings for 2024 (spoiler: George is top 10), Nick Willis' incredible sub-4 streak, Bowerman's latest departure, and more. You also don't want to miss one of our best Coffee Cauldron advice segments ever: Grant Fisher's secret admirer. Hope you guys enjoy!Follow us here: Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/coffeeclubpod/ Morgan McDonald: https://www.instagram.com/morganmcdonald__/ Olli Hoare: https://www.instagram.com/ollihoare/ George Beamish: https://www.instagram.com/georgebeamish/ Coffee Club Merch: https://coffeeclubpod.com Morgan's discord: https://discord.gg/uaCSeHDpgs Morgan's YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/@MorganMcDonaldisaloser

episodes.description: Jacob Kiplimo and Beatrice Chebet repeated at World XC but what happened to Agnes Ngetich and Joshua Cheptegei? April Fools came and went and what were the craziest stories in the sport in the last year? And it's not an April Fools joke that a Texas A&M Aggie ran an NCAA leading 1:44:46 and may be a dark horse candidate at the Olympic Trials. episodes.description: Jimmy Gressier, qui espère s’aligner sur le 5 000 m et le 10 000 m aux JO de Paris, est originaire du quartier du Chemin Vert, à Boulogne-sur-Mer. Dans « Quartiers Olympiques », il raconte son enfance difficile dans cette commune du Pas-de-Calais, les obstacles qu’il a du surmonter avec ses frères et sœurs, et son admiration pour les dockers. Interview et écriture : Apolline Convain. Montage : Léa Leostic. Création musicale : Matthieu Roques Lago. Rédaction en chef : Jean-Philippe Leclaire et Gaëtan Scherrer. Extraits : la chaine L’Equipe et « Dans la tête d’un lion ».Hébergé par Ausha. Visitez ausha.co/politique-de-confidentialite pour plus d'informations.

episodes.description: “I definitely feel like having that success indoors with the two titles helped me gain confidence in my ability to close down a race and win a race in any way. Whether it’s a fast race, slow race, I'm equally as confident. For the rest of the outdoor season, it definitely helped me be not as concerned as the gun went off that I was going to be able to close well off of any kind of race.” Newly minted Olympian Nico Young joins the show after qualifying for his first Olympic team in the 10,000m at the 2024 U.S. Olympic Trials. He also just announced signing a professional contract with adidas. Nico unpacks his third-place finish in the 10,000m, recaps his incredible NCAA season, shares about his excitement for Paris, breaks down his Mount Rushmore of NAU distance running legends, and lots more. Hear more from Nico in this episode of the CITIUS MAG Podcast. Overall       Good     Average     Bad     Engaging        Good     Average     Bad     Accurate        Good     Average     Bad     Tone       Good     Average     Bad     TranscriptFlute players hold a distinctive place in the world of music, enchanting audiences with their ability to produce a diverse array of tones and dynamics. The flute, a slender instrument made from gleaming metal or polished wood, may appear delicate, but it possesses a powerful voice that can range from hauntingly soft whispers to joyous, soaring melodies. With nimble fingers and expert breath control, flutists navigate intricate passages and convey profound emotions through their performances. Whether performing in orchestras, chamber ensembles, or as soloists, they captivate listeners with grace, precision, and the ability to transport them to realms of beauty and wonder.  This episode will explore the lives and careers of some of the greatest flute players of all time. Through their exceptional artistry, technical mastery, and expressive musicality, these musicians have left an indelible mark on the flute world. The episode will highlight their significant contributions to flute playing and pedagogy, showcasing how they have inspired generations of flutists and enriched the musical landscape. Geoffrey Gilbert stands as a monumental figure in the history of flute playing, revered for his exceptional musicianship, technical brilliance, and profound influence on the flute world. An English flutist, Gilbert’s career saw him assuming the role of principal flutist with several prestigious orchestras, including the London Symphony Orchestra and the Philharmonia Orchestra. His performances were characterized by an exquisite tone, flawless technique, and deeply expressive interpretations, leaving audiences spellbound.  Beyond his prowess as a performer, Gilbert was an ardent educator, imparting his vast knowledge and insights to students at renowned institutions worldwide. His pedagogical approach, emphasizing tone production, phrasing, and musicality, has had a lasting impact on the development of flutists. Many of his students have gone on to achieve significant success, spreading his teachings across the globe. Gilbert’s legacy as both a flutist and an educator continues to inspire and shape the flute community, ensuring that his influence endures through generations.  Shifting focus to another titan of the flute, Sir James Galway, often referred to as the “Man with the Golden Flute,” has captivated audiences worldwide with his virtuosity, expressive interpretations, and charismatic stage presence. Born in Belfast, Northern Ireland, Galway’s career has spanned several decades, during which he has become one of the most acclaimed flutists of his generation.  Galway’s extensive repertoire ranges from classical masterpieces to contemporary works and even popular tunes, all delivered with his signature warmth and precision. His recordings have achieved international acclaim, earning him numerous awards and accolades. Galway’s performances are marked by their technical brilliance, beautiful tone, and ability to connect deeply with audiences.  Beyond his solo career, Galway has collaborated with leading orchestras and musicians, leaving an indelible mark on the classical music landscape. His influence extends beyond performance; as a teacher and mentor, he continues to inspire generations of flutists with his passion and expertise. Sir James Galway’s contributions to the flute world have solidified his status as a living legend, celebrated for his extraordinary talent and enduring impact on music. Aurèle Nicolet, a Swiss flutist, distinguished himself as one of the leading flutists of the 20th century through his virtuosic technique and profound interpretations. Born in Neuchâtel, Switzerland, Nicolet honed his craft at the Paris Conservatoire under the tutelage of the renowned flutist Marcel Moyse. His career quickly ascended as he gained recognition as a soloist and chamber musician, performing with major orchestras and in prestigious venues around the globe.  Nicolet’s repertoire was notably diverse, spanning from the Baroque to contemporary music. He was especially revered for his performances of French and German flute music, bringing a depth of understanding and emotional resonance to each piece. His recordings remain a testament to his exceptional musicianship, continuing to inspire flutists with their technical brilliance and expressive power.  In addition to his illustrious performing career, Nicolet was a dedicated educator, serving on the faculty of the Basel Music Academy and the Freiburg University of Music. His teaching influenced generations of flutists, many of whom have gone on to successful careers in music. Aurèle Nicolet’s legacy is marked by his artistry, technique, and the profound musicality that he brought to every performance and teaching session.  Turning to another giant in the flute world, Jean-Pierre Rampal, a French virtuoso, is celebrated for his extraordinary talent and his pivotal role in popularizing the flute as a solo instrument. Born in Marseille, France, Rampal began his musical journey at a young age and quickly rose to prominence after winning first prize in flute at the Paris Conservatoire at just seventeen.  Rampal’s playing was characterized by exceptional technical skill, a beautiful tone, and expressive musicality. His repertoire encompassed a wide range of music, from Baroque to contemporary, with a particular affinity for Baroque music. Rampal played a significant role in bringing the flute to the forefront of the classical music world, commissioning new works and transcribing existing compositions to expand its repertoire.  His extensive recordings have left an indelible mark on the flute community, showcasing his artistry and technical prowess. With over one hundred recordings to his name, Rampal’s work remains highly regarded and continues to influence contemporary flute music. Beyond his performing career, he was a dedicated educator, serving on the faculties of the Paris Conservatoire and the Nice Conservatory. His instructional books on flute technique and interpretation are still widely used by flutists today.  Jean-Pierre Rampal’s contributions to the flute world are immense, and he is remembered as one of the greatest flutists in history. His exceptional skill, beautiful tone, and role in elevating the flute as a solo instrument have left a lasting legacy that continues to inspire flutists and music lovers worldwide. Marcel Moyse, a French flutist, is widely regarded as one of the most influential figures in the history of flute playing and pedagogy. Born in Saint-Amour, France, Moyse studied at the Paris Conservatoire and quickly gained recognition for his beautiful tone, expressive phrasing, and impeccable technique. His performing career included solo and chamber music engagements that captivated audiences with their emotional depth and technical precision.  However, Moyse's most enduring legacy lies in his contributions as a pedagogue. He revolutionized flute teaching with his innovative methods and influential instructional books, such as "Tone Development Through Interpretation," "De la Sonorité," and "Exercises Journaliers." These works have become essential reading for aspiring flutists, emphasizing the importance of a beautiful tone, expressive phrasing, and technical mastery. Moyse’s teaching philosophy focused on developing the musician's ability to convey emotion and character through their instrument.  His impact as a teacher was profound, with many of his students going on to become leading flutists and educators themselves. Moyse served on the faculty of the Paris Conservatoire and conducted masterclasses around the world, sharing his wisdom and insights with flutists of all levels. Marcel Moyse's legacy as a performer and educator continues to inspire and shape the flute community, ensuring his place as a monumental figure in the history of the instrument.  In stark contrast to Moyse's classical approach, Robert Dick, an American flutist and composer, has made significant contributions to contemporary music and extended techniques. Known for his innovative approach to flute playing, Dick has expanded the expressive possibilities of the instrument, pushing the boundaries of traditional flute techniques. His unique vocabulary of sounds includes multiphonics, glissandi, and percussive effects, creating rich and dynamic performances that challenge conventional expectations of flute music.  Dick's work encompasses a wide range of styles and genres, from classical to jazz to avant-garde. He is renowned for his pioneering spirit, constantly exploring new sonic landscapes and incorporating unconventional sounds and textures into his compositions. As a prolific composer, his catalog includes solo pieces, chamber music, and works for orchestra, reflecting his innovative approach to music.  In addition to his work as a performer and composer, Dick is a dedicated educator. He has written several books on flute technique and improvisation, sharing his unique approach with students and musicians worldwide. His teaching emphasizes creativity and exploration, encouraging flutists to push the limits of their instrument and discover new modes of expression.  Robert Dick's visionary contributions to flute playing have inspired a new generation of flutists to explore the expressive possibilities of the instrument. His pioneering work in contemporary music and extended techniques has left a lasting impact on the flute community, making him a seminal figure in the evolution of flute performance and pedagogy. Jeanne Baxtresser stands as a beacon of excellence in the world of flute playing, celebrated for her remarkable artistry and technical brilliance. Her illustrious career is highlighted by her tenure as the principal flutist of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra, a position she held for over a decade. During her time with the orchestra, Baxtresser's performances were characterized by their exquisite tone, impeccable phrasing, and captivating expressiveness, earning her widespread acclaim and admiration.  Beyond her orchestral achievements, Baxtresser is also an accomplished soloist and chamber musician, captivating audiences worldwide with her dynamic performances. Her contributions to the flute community extend far beyond the concert stage. As a dedicated educator, she has inspired countless flutists through her teaching at leading conservatories and music schools. Baxtresser’s pedagogical approach emphasizes musicality, technique, and the development of a beautiful tone, shaping the next generation of flutists with her profound insights and expertise.  Her legacy as a flutist and educator continues to influence and inspire musicians worldwide, cementing her status as one of the finest flutists of her generation. Jeanne Baxtresser’s impact on the flute world is enduring, marked by her exceptional artistry and unwavering commitment to excellence.  Transitioning to another contemporary master, Emmanuel Pahud is a world-renowned flutist known for his extraordinary talent, technical prowess, and captivating performances. Born in Switzerland, Pahud rose to prominence at a young age, winning prestigious competitions and establishing himself as one of the leading flutists of his generation. His playing is characterized by its impeccable technique, exquisite tone, and expressive depth, captivating audiences and critics alike.  Pahud's repertoire is remarkably diverse, encompassing a wide range of musical styles from Baroque to contemporary. He has collaborated with esteemed orchestras and conductors around the globe, delivering performances that showcase his versatility and artistry. His recordings have received critical acclaim, further cementing his reputation as a preeminent flutist of our time.  In addition to his performing career, Pahud is deeply committed to music education. He shares his knowledge and passion for the flute through masterclasses and educational initiatives, inspiring young flutists to reach new heights in their musical journeys. Emmanuel Pahud’s dedication to both performance and education ensures his lasting influence on the flute community, making him a significant figure in the world of classical music.  Together, Jeanne Baxtresser and Emmanuel Pahud exemplify the pinnacle of flute artistry. Their exceptional careers, marked by technical brilliance and profound musicality, continue to inspire and shape the future of flute playing. Their contributions to both performance and education have left an indelible mark on the flute community, ensuring their legacies will be celebrated for generations to come. Julius Baker, an American flutist, is celebrated for his exceptional artistry, technical mastery, and influential teaching career. Born in Cleveland, Ohio, Baker quickly rose to prominence, establishing himself as one of the foremost flutists of the 20th century. His performances were renowned for their beautiful tone, expressive playing, and impeccable technique, captivating audiences worldwide.  Baker's contributions to the flute world extend far beyond his performances. As a dedicated educator, he served on the faculties of prestigious institutions such as the Juilliard School, the Curtis Institute of Music, and the Manhattan School of Music. His teaching was characterized by exacting standards and a profound commitment to musical excellence. Baker's ability to inspire and guide his students helped shape many successful careers in music, ensuring his influence would endure through generations of flutists.  In addition to his teaching, Baker was a prolific recording artist, leaving behind a rich legacy of recordings that continue to be admired for their beauty and artistry. His interpretations of the standard flute repertoire, including works by Bach, Mozart, and Debussy, remain benchmarks for flutists today. Julius Baker's legacy as a performer and educator has left an indelible mark on the flute community, celebrating his contributions to the world of music.  William Kincaid, another towering figure in the flute world, is renowned for his brilliant technique, lyrical style, and lasting impact on flute pedagogy. Born in Minneapolis, Minnesota, Kincaid began playing the flute at a young age and quickly demonstrated exceptional talent. He studied at the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia, where he later became the principal flute teacher, succeeding his own teacher, Georges Barrère.  Kincaid's career was marked by his role as principal flutist of the Philadelphia Orchestra, a position he held for over 40 years. Under the batons of conductors such as Leopold Stokowski and Eugene Ormandy, Kincaid's playing was characterized by its meticulous approach, emphasizing tone production, intonation, and phrasing. His performances were celebrated for their expressive depth and technical precision, earning him widespread acclaim.  As a teacher, Kincaid was highly influential, producing a generation of flutists who went on to achieve significant success in the music world. His teaching emphasized a singing, lyrical style of playing, and he was known for his ability to draw out the best in his students. Kincaid's legacy lives on through his students, who continue to spread his teachings and uphold his high standards of excellence.  Overall, William Kincaid is remembered as a legendary figure in the flute world, admired for his artistry, his teaching, and his lasting impact on flute playing and pedagogy. His contributions to the Philadelphia Orchestra and his influential role as an educator have left an enduring legacy that continues to inspire flutists around the globe.  Together, Julius Baker and William Kincaid represent the pinnacle of flute artistry and education. Their exceptional careers, marked by beautiful tone, expressive playing, and influential teaching, have left an indelible mark on the flute community. Their contributions to both performance and pedagogy continue to inspire and shape the future of flute playing, ensuring their legacies will be celebrated for generations to come.          .done-button-podcast {     display: inline-block;     margin: 18px 0 0;     padding: 0 8px;     background: #622bff;     border: none;     border-radius: 8px;     color: white;     }          Get your podcast on AnyTopic
